unnormalised: So, someone asked about finding addresses for govt offices, and it can be a real pain, right? Especially if you're like me and still end up calling the wrong place even after Googling!
normalised: So, someone asked about finding addresses for government offices, and it can be a real pain, right? Especially if you're like me and still end up calling the wrong place even after Googling!

unnormalised: First things first, try the official websites. Seriously. The Ministry of Education, for example, might list all the Regional Offices with their addresses, like maybe "Regional Office, CBSE, Block A, Sector 5, Panchkula, Haryana, 134109." You'd think everyone does this, but nah. Sometimes you'll find old circulars with addresses that are probably outdated. Fun times!
normalised: First things first, try the official websites. Seriously. The Ministry of Education, for example, might list all the Regional Offices with their addresses, like maybe "Regional Office, C-B-S-E, Block A, Sector five, Panchkula, Haryana, one three four one zero nine." You'd think everyone does this, but nah. Sometimes you'll find old circulars with addresses that are probably outdated. Fun times!

unnormalised: Then, there's the whole "pin code confusion." You THINK you know it, but then the courier guy is yelling at you because "Sector 62, Noida, UP" is apparently DIFFERENT from "Sector 62, Gautam Budh Nagar, UP" even though...it's the same place! And don’t even get me started on the countless variations of spellings. Like is it "Bengaluru" or "Bangalore" when you’re trying to send something to the Indian Institute of Science (IISc)? Their official website probably says "IISc, Bangalore, Karnataka, 560012", but good luck guessing that.
normalised: Then, there's the whole "pin code confusion." You THINK you know it, but then the courier guy is yelling at you because "Sector sixty two, Noida, U-P" is apparently DIFFERENT from "Sector sixty two, Gautam Budh Nagar, U-P" even though...it's the same place! And don’t even get me started on the countless variations of spellings. Like is it "Bengaluru" or "Bangalore" when you’re trying to send something to the Indian Institute of Science (I-I-S-c)? Their official website probably says "I-I-S-c, Bangalore, Karnataka, five six zero zero one two", but good luck guessing that.

unnormalised: Another thing is trying to figure out which "Bhavan" is which. There's Krishi Bhavan, Rail Bhavan, Udyog Bhavan...all in Delhi, all housing important govt depts. Good luck figuring out which one you need without a very specific office name. Like the Department of Agriculture is probably in Krishi Bhavan, Rafi Marg, New Delhi, 110001, but WHICH FLOOR?!
normalised: Another thing is trying to figure out which "Bhavan" is which. There's Krishi Bhavan, Rail Bhavan, Udyog Bhavan...all in Delhi, all housing important government departments. Good luck figuring out which one you need without a very specific office name. Like the Department of Agriculture is probably in Krishi Bhavan, Rafi Marg, New Delhi, one one zero zero zero one, but WHICH FLOOR?!

unnormalised: Also, don't underestimate the power of local knowledge. Your auto-rickshaw driver bhai probably knows where the local municipal office is better than Google Maps. Seriously. They might even know it's "Behind the Hanuman Mandir, Near the Old Post Office, Ward No. 7, Thane, Maharashtra, 400601," even if Google just says "Municipal Office, Thane."
normalised: Also, don't underestimate the power of local knowledge. Your auto-rickshaw driver bhai probably knows where the local municipal office is better than Google Maps. Seriously. They might even know it's "Behind the Hanuman Mandir, Near the Old Post Office, Ward Number seven, Thane, Maharashtra, four zero zero six zero one," even if Google just says "Municipal Office, Thane."

unnormalised: Plus, there's always the classic "landmark" problem. "Opposite SBI Main Branch, Near Town Hall, Shimla, HP 171001" sounds helpful, right? Until you realize Shimla has like, 50 SBI branches! And which Town Hall are we talking about? The old one? The new one? The slightly-less-old one?
normalised: Plus, there's always the classic "landmark" problem. "Opposite S-B-I Main Branch, Near Town Hall, Shimla, H-P one seven one zero zero one" sounds helpful, right? Until you realize Shimla has like, fifty S-B-I branches! And which Town Hall are we talking about? The old one? The new one? The slightly-less-old one?

unnormalised: But seriously, start with the official website, then double-check the pin code, and if all else fails, ask a local. And maybe pack some chai and biscuits for the journey. You'll probably need them. Good luck navigating the maze of Indian government addresses! You'll get there eventually. Maybe.
normalised: But seriously, start with the official website, then double-check the pin code, and if all else fails, ask a local. And maybe pack some chai and biscuits for the journey. You'll probably need them. Good luck navigating the maze of Indian government addresses! You'll get there eventually. Maybe.
